title: 115_s362
content: The Act titled "Federal Employees Paid Parental Leave Act of 2017" provides paid parental leave for Executive Branch employees. The Federal Employees Paid Parental Leave Act of 2017 allows employees to substitute paid leave for any leave without pay, including 6 weeks of paid parental leave and accrued annual or sick leave. The Paid Parental Leave Act allows employees to use paid parental leave without using other types of leave first. The paid parental leave is payable from agency funds, not considered annual or vacation leave, and does not carry over if unused after 12 months. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management can create regulations to increase the amount of leave. The Paid Parental Leave Act allows employees to use paid parental leave without using other types of leave first. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management may increase the amount of paid parental leave to a maximum of 12 administrative workweeks, considering benefits to the government, costs, trends in other sectors, and the government's role as an employer. The Paid Parental Leave Act allows employees to designate days for paid parental leave, with the Director of the Office of Personnel Management considering various factors. Additionally, amendments are made to Section 114(n) of title 49, United States Code, regarding TSA personnel management. The Paid Parental Leave Act allows employees to designate days for paid parental leave under the personnel management system for Transportation Security Administration employees. This includes the ability to substitute paid leave for any unpaid leave under family and medical leave, in accordance with title 5. Conforming amendments are made to Section 111(d) of the Aviation and Transportation Security Act. Section 111(d) of the Aviation and Transportation Security Act is amended to include provisions for family and medical leave, including paid parental leave, for security screening personnel. This allows them to substitute paid leave for any unpaid leave under family and medical leave, in accordance with title 5. The amendments made by this section regarding family and medical leave, including paid parental leave, apply to births or placements occurring 6 months after the enactment of the Act. Paid parental leave for congressional employees is provided for in Section 3 of the Act. Amendment to the Congressional Accountability Act allows covered employees to substitute paid leave for unpaid leave under the Family and Medical Leave Act for parental leave. The Congressional Accountability Act amendment permits covered employees to use paid leave for parental leave, including paid parental leave weeks equivalent to federal employees and any additional vacation or sick leave provided by the employer. No requirement to exhaust other leave before using paid leave. The Congressional Accountability Act amendment allows covered employees to use paid parental leave without needing to use other leave first. Paid parental leave must be used within a 12-month period and does not accumulate for future use. The Congressional Accountability Act amendment allows covered employees to use paid parental leave within 12 months of birth or placement, starting 6 months after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENT TO FAMILY AND MEDICAL LEAVE ACT FOR GAO AND LIBRARY OF CONGRESS EMPLOYEES. Amendment to the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 allows employees of the Government Accountability Office and Library of Congress to substitute paid leave for family and medical leave. The amendment allows employees to use paid parental leave corresponding to federal employees' leave and any additional vacation or sick leave provided by the employer, without requiring the use of other leave first. The amendment allows for paid parental leave to be used by employees without the need to use other leave first. Paid parental leave must be used within a 12-month period and will not accumulate for future use. The effective date for these changes is 6 months after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION FOR MEMBERS OF THE NATIONAL GUARD AND RESERVES. Employees of the Executive Branch and TSA who are members of the National Guard or Reserves are eligible for leave under specific circumstances. Service on active duty will be counted as service for leave purposes. Employees who are members of the National Guard or Reserves in the Executive Branch and TSA are eligible for leave under certain conditions. Active duty service will be considered as employee service for leave eligibility. Employees in the Executive Branch and TSA who are members of the National Guard or Reserves can count their active duty service towards their eligibility for leave under the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993. This includes service in covered active duty and applies to employees of the Government Accountability Office or Library of Congress as well. Employees in the Executive Branch and TSA who are National Guard or Reserves members can count their active duty service towards eligibility for leave under the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993. This includes service in covered active duty and applies to employees of the Government Accountability Office or Library of Congress as well. Additionally, any service on covered active duty by an employee shall be counted as time employed for purposes of the Act. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 5 years of the Act's enactment, detailing the implementation and impact of the Act on parental leave usage and employee recruitment and retention.
